questions.question: What is the main purpose of an activity diagram?
questions.option_a: A. To model the data structure of a system
questions.option_b: B. To represent workflows and system behavior
questions.option_c: C. To design the user interface layout
questions.explanation: Activity diagrams represent workflows by modeling activities and their dependencies.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common use of activity diagrams?
questions.explanation: Activity diagrams are not used for database schema design; they focus on workflows and processes.

questions.question: What shape represents the Initial/Start node in an activity diagram?
questions.explanation: The initial/start node is represented by a filled circle in UML activity diagrams.

questions.question: Which symbol represents the Final Node in an activity diagram?
questions.option_b: B. Filled circle with another circle around it
questions.explanation: The final node is shown as a filled circle within another circle.

questions.question: Which element is represented by a rounded rectangle in activity diagrams?
questions.explanation: Actions are represented as rounded rectangles with a verb phrase inside.

questions.question: What is another name for a transition in activity diagrams?
questions.explanation: Transitions are also called control flows, showing the movement from one action to another.

questions.question: Which UML symbol represents a decision/branch point?
questions.explanation: A decision node is represented by a diamond shape with guard conditions.

questions.question: In a decision node, what is required for each branch?
questions.explanation: Each branch of a decision must have a guard condition to determine the flow.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a merge node?
questions.option_a: A. To split one flow into multiple flows
questions.option_b: B. To join multiple flows into one after branching
questions.option_c: C. To mark the end of a process
questions.explanation: Merge nodes combine multiple branches back into a single control flow.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a fork node?
questions.option_a: A. Splits control flow into multiple concurrent paths
questions.option_b: B. Merges multiple flows into one
questions.explanation: A fork splits a single flow into two or more concurrent flows.

questions.question: What must every fork in an activity diagram have?
questions.explanation: Every fork should have a corresponding join to synchronize the parallel flows.

questions.question: Which symbol is used to represent a join?
questions.explanation: A join is shown using a thick bar to indicate synchronization of multiple flows.

questions.question: Which UML notation represents a sub-activity?
questions.option_a: A. Action box with rake-style symbol
questions.explanation: Sub-activities are shown with a rake-style symbol inside the action box.

questions.question: What notation indicates an action may need to be repeated?
questions.option_c: C. Asterisk (*) inside an action state
questions.explanation: An asterisk inside an action state shows iteration in activity diagrams.

questions.question: What is a common mistake with forks in activity diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Thinking control flows down only one path
questions.option_b: B. Using them to end a process
questions.option_c: C. Forgetting to include guard conditions
questions.option_d: D. Confusing them with final nodes
questions.explanation: A fork sends control down all paths, unlike a decision node where only one path is taken.

questions.question: Which concept in activity diagrams is similar to 'ENDIF' in pseudocode?
questions.explanation: Merge nodes represent the UML equivalent of ENDIF, combining paths back together.

questions.question: Which partitioning technique organizes actions by organizational units?
questions.explanation: Swimlanes are used to partition activity diagrams by actors or organizational units.

questions.question: In swimlane notation, how are partitions usually drawn?
questions.option_b: B. Parallel horizontal or vertical lines
questions.explanation: Swimlanes are shown as parallel lines (horizontal or vertical) dividing responsibilities.

questions.question: Which of the following best represents a 'transition'?
questions.option_a: A. It indicates the start of an activity diagram.
questions.option_b: B. It connects activity nodes showing control flow.
questions.option_c: C. It partitions the diagram into swimlanes.
questions.explanation: Transitions connect actions to show how control flows from one to the next.

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct guard condition example?
questions.explanation: Guards are written in square brackets, such as [valid member].

questions.question: Which activity example from the lecture involves uploading an ID and payment slip?
questions.explanation: Registering for LMS membership involves uploading ID and payment slip.

questions.question: In the flight booking example, what is the default baggage allowance for Business Class?
questions.explanation: Business Class passengers have a default baggage allowance of 40 KG.

questions.question: Which activity example highlights the use of concurrency?
questions.explanation: The Order Processing System involves multiple departments working in parallel, showing concurrency.

questions.question: Which is a correct description of an action node?
questions.option_b: B. A sequence of activities enclosed in a diamond
questions.option_c: C. A task represented in a rounded rectangle with a verb phrase
questions.option_d: D. Indicates the end of workflow
questions.explanation: Actions are tasks shown in rounded rectangles, labeled with present-tense verb phrases.

questions.question: Which mistake should be avoided when drawing loops in activity diagrams?
questions.option_c: C. Using sub-activities instead of iterations
questions.explanation: Loops must clearly include guard conditions to show termination criteria.
